title: Projects
text:
Communication Sciences and Disorders (CSD) Bilingüe Suite
Given the increasing Latine Spanish-speaking population, and the gap in the availability of multilingual SLPs and AuDs service providers in the US, the CSD Bilingüe Suite serves as an innovative initiative designed to foster a dynamic space for professional development in the fields of speech, language, and hearing sciences in order to close this gap. The task force focuses on developing plain language skills in Spanish and English while practicing cultural humility to enrich students’ learning and readiness in serving and engaging with culturally and linguistically diverse communities, specifically, the Latine population.
Long-term Objectives:

Equip undergraduate and graduate students with the essential skills needed to become bilingual SLPs or AuDs, while empowering them to advocate for the needs of culturally and linguistically diverse communities
Raise awareness of the CSD field among underrepresented undergraduate students to encourage enrollment in the Communication Sciences and Disorders (COSI) major at CWRU, while providing resources to support their success throughout the program
Create bilingual resources to explain the CSD field, SLP and AuD professions, and communication disorders, targeting students, clinicians, and Spanish-speaking parents/caregivers in order to improve understanding and provide culturally relevant support

Case Western Reserve University: Innovation Week 2024 - Poster Pitch

American Speech-Language Hearing Association (ASHA): 2023 Convention - Virtual Poster

Master’s Thesis
Lopez, C. (2023). Hispanic/Latine Parents’ Perceptions, Understanding, and Satisfaction With Speech and Language Services in Schools (Order No. 30639382). Available from ProQuest Dissertations & Theses A&I; ProQuest Dissertations & Theses Global; Publicly Available Content Database. (2866282426). https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/hispanic-latine-parents-perceptions-understanding/docview/2866282426/se-2

title: Cassandra Lopez
text: My interest in research was ignited during my undergraduate career at Case Western Reserve University (CWRU), where I had the opportunity of working as a research assistant in Dr. Lauren Calandruccio’s Speech and Auditory Research Lab. In this role, I became deeply fascinated by the transformative power of research in the development of assessments, evidence-based practices, and instruments to address varying communication disorders. As a native Spanish speaker and Latine individual, I have a unique awareness on how cultural and linguistic factors can impact Latine families’ access to education, resources, and interventions for communication disorders. This personal perspective has fueled my commitment to advancing the limited research on bilingual populations and individuals who speak a language other than English. After graduating CWRU, I pursued my master’s degree in Speech-Language Pathology with a Bilingual Track at Indiana University, Bloomington. While working closely with Spanish-English bilingual families, I observed the critical shortage of bilingual prevention, assessments, treatment tools, and multilingual speech-language pathologists (SLPs) and Audiologists (AuDs). This gap creates significant barriers to receiving and delivering culturally and linguistically responsive services, further underlining the need for increased bilingual resources and clinicians.

title: Cassandra Lopez
text:
Professional and Clinical Experience
Southwest Cook County Cooperative Association for Special Education (SWCCCASE) | Chicago, IL
August 2023 – July 2024
Clinical Fellow in Speech-Language Pathology + Special Education Co-Teacher

Conducted speech and language evaluations for students in grades 3rd through 5th
Collaborated daily with co-teacher and social worker on academic and functional teaching plans
Developed and implemented speech and language therapy goals for students diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), Emotional Disturbance (ED), Hearing Impairment (HI), and Other Health Impairments (OHI)

Northwestern Medicine Marianjoy Rehabilitation Hospital | Wheaton, IL
March 2023 – June 2023
Graduate Extern in Speech-Language Pathology: Stroke Unit

Facilitated individual and group meal training sessions focused on swallowing strategies and recommendations
Implemented treatment plans for adult patients (ages 26 to 98) directed by supervising speech-language pathologist
Conducted, documented, and reported on speech, language, cognitive, and swallowing evaluations for monolingual and bilingual adult patients

Naperville Community Unit School District 203 | Chicago, IL
January 2023 – March 2023
Graduate Extern in Speech-Language Pathology

Conducted and documented monolingual and bilingual speech and language evaluations
Reported speech and language assessment and performance data during Individualized Education Plan (IEP) meetings
Implemented treatment plans for students in Pre-K through 5th grade across 4 schools as directed by speech-language pathologists

title: Cassandra Lopez
text:
Research Experience
Speech and Auditory Research (SpAR) Laboratory | Cleveland, OH
August 2024 – Present
Graduate Research Assistant

Document and track lab project tasks
Lead stimuli development for Spanish speech recognition tests
Contribute to editing and refining undergraduate research papers and posters

Master’s Thesis | Bloomington, IN
January 2022 – July 2023
Graduate Clinical Researcher

Designed and administrated a qualitative research study regarding Hispanic/Latine parents’ perceptions, understanding, and satisfaction with their children’s school-based speech-language pathology services
Recruited, consented, and interviewed 7 parent participants
Analyzed parent interviews and surveys utilizing thematic analysis

Language Experience and Multilingualism Research (LEMuR) Laboratory | Bloomington, IN
January 2022 – December 2022
Graduate Research Assistant

Translated Institutional Review Board (IRB) documents and research materials from English to Spanish
Contributed to the development of an online research study on Gorilla Experiment Builder focused on word learning for bilingual children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)

Speech and Auditory Research (SpAR) Laboratory | Cleveland, OH
January 2018 – June 2021
Undergraduate Research Assistant

Administered over 100 hearing screenings for research purposes
Led data collection for a five-person team and analyzed speech perception reports
Recruited, consented, and tested 150+ research participants for speech and auditory studies

title: Welcome to my website!
text:
Github
  
  
    
     LinkedIn
  
  
    
     Email
  




Welcome to my website!
I am a first-year PhD student at Case Western Reserve University specializing in Speech-Language Pathology with a focus on bilingualism. I am also a certified and licensed Bilingual Speech-Language Pathologist (SLP) in the state of Illinois. I have clinical experience working in school, hospital, and clinical settings. I received my undergraduate degree in Communication Sciences and Psychology from Case Western Reserve University and completed my graduate degree in Speech-Language Pathology on a Spanish-English Bilingual Track at Indiana University - Bloomington.
On this website, you will find a variety of resources showcasing my work, including scholarly articles, brochures, and posters. You will also find news and updates on my current research projects, as well as information on upcoming events and conferences where I will be speaking. As one of the 9% multilingual speech-language pathologists in the nation, I invite you to explore my life’s work on the development of culturally and linguistically responsive resources for individuals and families experiencing communication disorders.
Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions or would like to discuss potential projects.
